description.text:
This is a Zelda Triforce fidget spinner that I put together from pieces across Thingiverse. I added to the main part (Triforce spinner) to include a texture along the rim of the spinner so that there is something to feel with finger when spinning.

The caps have added embossing of Wind Waker themed logos as well as Hylian crest on a cap and twisted spindle cap.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2 Extended

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm (spinner) and .3mm (caps)

Infill:

50%

Notes:

NOTE: I only used supports for the caps as they are standing upright. It's possible that flipping (most of) them would help; however, since there was embossing on the tops, I opted to keep those facing up. Couple of the hylian crest caps protrude out, so facing those to the plate wasn't an option.

Also no rafts/brim was used as I had PEI on the plate.

Positioning? Setup? Possible unecessary extra cleanup

The caps file has two twisted caps in the mix, which work well for even just locking together with no bearing and spinning (pure fidget, no continuous spin). However, when printing, they are positioned across from each other with a short cap in the middle. When I printed, there was some extra cleanup to get strings of filament off the center one. If I print these again, I will likely reposition those so they are next to each other.

Texture added to give nice feel when sliding finger across to spin (or just hold) Some background to texture

This is the main part that I contributed uniquely to the final product. I created a shallow tetrahedron and positioned/duplicated it into a triforce and copied it onto a rectangle the length of the side. Using an inverted tetrahedron (inverted both top/bottom and front/back) in the middle of the tetrahedron triforce, I subtracted it from the rectangle that the string of triforces were on. Then repeated the steps for the 'Lorule' triforces (upside down triforces). Once the rectangle was complete, just copy/position to other sides.

Ideally I would've/should've done this to the edge of the triforce itself, but then it's more difficult to duplicate, since I was subtracting the middle triangle.

description.text:
Split flap displays were widely used in railway stations, airports etc. I loved watching the boards of the rolling characters. They have mostly been replaced with electronic devices nowadays, The module here is based on a popular cheap stepper motor, 28BYJ-48, driven by arduino. The design represents a single position of a character. It can store 32 characters in it (this is the number of flaps). The motor is hidden inside the body cylinder, so the duplicated devices can be easily placed in a row to make the entire words. No pulleys, no timing belts.

Note 1. The design does not contain any handle. Use two M4 screws to mount it to your preferred base or drill whatever holes you need in the motor holder piece. I used a thick wire to make the temporary stand.

Note 2. The thick wire is also used to set the flipping point of the top flap in this prototype. It was the easiest way to tune the correct position; however, it's just a stopgap solution. For the final design it could be printed extension of the handle or just the front panel.

Note 3. There is no position sensor. The driver keeps counting the steps to identify the currently displayed character. It is not reliable method though. The motor does not make the perfect angle per step, probably due to the gearing. It can be dealt with by adjusting the driver code, but in the long run this particular split-flap is better suited to work as a dice than a display :-)

Enjoy the flipping!

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Keep the flaps thin, max 1mm. I used 3 layers for the flat surface, and fourth layer just for the hinges. This specific item contains a few thicker flaps, for testing purposes. They work less reliable as you can see on the video. The empty characters flip considerably faster than others.

The main body consists of two parts. They fit together tight enough not to require any screws. Slide the blades into the grooves. Do not push the pieces to the very end initially. Leave a few mm gap in order to insert the flaps. Inserting the flaps is easier in this position. When all done, push the two body pieces together. The body is attached directly to the motor shaft by push. The motor is mounted to its holder part using two M4 screws. The image above shows just the idea. The motor should be insert into the body only when the body is already finished with flaps on it. The best way to cut the letters is using the spouse. Silhouettes or printed rectangles, anything should work! I wish my spouse were making stands as well. Unfortunately, this task was on me.
Designed in Blender 2.78a

Dead simple split-flap display at work! The Driver

Due to the popular demand I hereby provide an example driver to run this device:
https://github.com/hakernia/DeadSimpleSplitFlapDisplay
Multi unit version to be added later.

Code:

include

include

ifdef AVR

include <avr/power.h>

define PIN 6

define NUMPIXELS 1

//==============Defining variables for fix_fft=======================
int x = 0;
char im[128], data[128];
char data_avgs[14];
int i = 0, val, steady;
int l = 0;

Adafruit_NeoPixel pixel = Adafruit_NeoPixel(NUMPIXELS, PIN, NEO_GRB + NEO_KHZ800);

void setup() {
Serial.begin(9600);
pixel.begin();
pixel.show();
}

void loop()
{
//===================FFT algorithm=======================
for (i = 0; i < 128; i++)
{
val = analogRead(A9);
steady = val;
data[i] = val;
im[i] = 0;
}

fix_fft(data, im, 7, 0);

for (i = 0; i < 64; i++)
{
data[i] = sqrt(data[i] data[i] + im[i] im[i]);
}

for (i = 0; i < 14; i++)
{
data_avgs[i] = data[i 4] + data[i 4 + 1] + data[i 4 + 2] + data[i 4 + 3];
data_avgs[i] = map(data_avgs[i], 0, 30, 0, 9);
}
int value = data_avgs[0];
Serial.print("Time domain: ");
Serial.println(steady);
Serial.print("Frequency domain: ");
Serial.println(value);
delay(100);
pixel.setPixelColor(0, 75, 0, 130); //change color here by changing RGB values. In this case R=150, G=150, B=150
int bValue = map(value, 0, 30, 0, 255);
pixel.setBrightness(bValue);
pixel.show();
}

title: Pokemon Chess Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pokemon chess set I made for a friends birthday.
Printed in light Woodfill PLA, sanded, stained and sprayed with a clear coat.

Every piece is designed to be printed in 2 parts, the Pokeball base and the Pokemon itself.
The base can be filled with nuts (M8 at 100% size, M6 at 75%) to make the pieces more bottom heavy.

To better differentiate the pieces they have different base shapes:
-Pawn = round
-King & Queen = pentagon
-Bishop = hexagon
-Knight = heptagon
-Rook = octagon

We tested it and it's barely harder than with a regular chess set to tell the pieces apart :)

comments.text:
Does it clog the nozzle?
That always happened with my printer.
I used a 0.5mm hardened steel nozzle, because the woodfill is too abrasive for brass nozzles.
I found that lower temperatures are better, because at higher temperatures the wood starts to char and will clog the nozzle.
185-190°C and 40-60mm/s worked for me.
It still failed to print sometimes, but that was because of the complicated geometry of some of the models...
I'd recommend starting with the bases, and when you have the settings dialed in you can start with the Pokemons.
comments.author: Star4ce

My Setup:
  • Motors Turnigy C2226 1800kv
  • 60x50 propellers
  • ESC Turnigy Plush 10A
  • MicroWii flight controller board.
  • Fatshark 250 mW video transmitter.
  • Fatshark FPV camera.
  • GoPro Hero 3 camera.
    Recommended setup:
  • Upgrade to specialized motors like SunnySky X2204S 2300kv, Lumenier FX2206-13 2000kv, Tiger MN-1806 2300kv or RCTimer HP1806 2300kv. Use 5030 propellers.
  • Mobius HD camera (lightweight).
  • SimonK 12A ESC.

For the bottom plate assembly, you will need:
  • 12 x M3 16mm screws
  • 4 x M3 lock nuts
  • 4 x M3 nylon spacers (~15 mm)
  • 4 x M3 7mm screws
    • For the top plate assembly, you will need:
  • 8 x 37 mm nylon/aluminum spacers
  • 8 x M3 7mm screws
    • OR
  • 8 x 30 mm spacers
  • 8 x M3 12~16mm screws
  • Print the 7 mm spacers (mini_h_quad_spacers.stl).
    • OR
  • 8 x 35 mm spacers
  • 8 x M3 7 mm screws
  • File the part 'mini_h_quad_cam.stl' in order to fit a 35mm inter-plate space.

title: Mosfet Mount Snap on Board fits Tronxy P802

description.text:
This remix is for externally mounting a separate MOSFET to switch power to the heated bed or extruder. By removing the load from your controller we are able to prolong it's life and are allowed the option to run more power though to the powered device away from, and isolated from your controller in order to get the job done. Mounting holes are located where pre-existing holes exist on a P802 but can be mounted anywhere you can drill two 3mm holes. Snap fasteners will save you from further pilfering the goody bag of screws that came with your printer to mount the board and are non-conductive.

It's quite sturdy at 10% fill so no worries it won't empty your roll making one.

title: Custom Ducting for Node 202 Case and EVGA ACX 3 Graphics

description.text:
Computer case ducting, custom made for the Fractal Design Node 202 case when used with an EVGA ACX3 graphics card. (also includes alternative CPU dust filter panel compatible with Scythe Big Shuriken 2 cooler or similar)

The graphics card ducts sit between the case and graphics card, forcing air to be pulled from the outside of the case rather than recirculating hot air. The ducts are attached using M3 countersunk screws (I used 12 mm, could be shorter). This allows the dust filter to just about fit over the top of them.

The alternative dust filter is thinner than the original to accomodate a Scythe Big Shuriken 2 aftermarket cooler. (Dust mesh material required)

description.text: This piston has a cylinder head, so it can be powered on the up and down stroke. Another entry for the Makerbot giveaway.

remixed_from.author: Tech2C
remixed_from.title: E3Dv6 Bowden X-carriage mount v2 for Prusa i3

description.text:
Behold the most legendary of extruder mounts for the HICTOP 3DP family of 3D printers! Powered by the greatness of the E3D Cyclops & Chimera Dual Extrusion System, this mount brings multi-material printing to the HICTOP 3DP family printers in a whole new way.

Inspired by Tech2C's E3Dv6 Bowden X-carriage mount v2 for Prusa i3, this mount provides a clean, simple, and expandable means of adding multi-material printing to your printer. In addition to the carriage itself, I've also included attachments for the BLTouch probe, 12mm and 18mm inductive and capacitive probes, and a cable chain adapter for DarkDragonWing's awesome cable chain setup. I've also included a coupler plate that optionally allows the use of PC4-M10 push-in fittings in place of the embedded couplers in the Cyclops & Chimera heatsink. Finally, the fan duct has been redesigned to accommodate the dual nozzles in the Chimera setup.

The design utilizes the existing M4 screws for the pillow blocks, but you will need two additional M4x8 screws for the bottom two attachments that are normally unused on the standard HICTOP carriage. The fan duct is attached with M3x6 screws, the blower fan with M3x20 screws, and the probe mounts and cable chain mount with M3x10 screws. M3 nuts are also needed for the probe mount, cable chain mount, and to attach the standard HICTOP X belt holder. The E3D hotend is attached with M3x8 screws if not using the coupler plate, or M3x12 screws if the coupler plate is used.

The E3D Cyclops & Chimera does require conversion to a Bowden feed setup, and E3D recommends a geared extruder for the Cyclops. I've had good luck with VanessaEzekowitz's Greg's B'Wadestruder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1831961).

Your printer will require new firmware in order to utilize the E3D Cyclops & Chimera. I've created example configurations for the HICTOP 3DP-11 modified into this configuration, which can be viewed at:

https://github.com/tcm0116/Marlin/tree/cyclops
https://github.com/tcm0116/Marlin/tree/chimera

Please don't hesitate to ask in the comments if you have any questions. Enjoy!

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

I strongly recommend printing these parts with PETG or ABS. I personally used PETG with great success.

Blokus is a fun game to play. The only problem is that the full size game board is basically designed as a 4 player game. The published 2 player option is for each player to use 2 colors. I wanted to keep it simple and decided to print another full set of same color tiles for each player. The other option is to play a single color each on a smaller board. This can be achieved on the full size board with a frame.
These are the 2 player options that are included in the zip file:

Additional Tile Set - To use 2 sets of the same color tiles on the full size board (20x20).
Blokus Duo Board (14x14) - When using 1 set of tiles for each player.
Blokus Duo Frame (14x14) - When using the full size board (20x20) and 1 set of tiles for each player. The Blokus Duo Frame consists of 8 tiles arranged as in the photo.

Full size board is not supplied since it is larger than most print beds.

I make no claims of any kind regarding the Blokus board game.

This is a piston that fits in 2 in pvc for a piston valve meant for a air cannon it has a one way valve to increase performance.
To assemble it you need a: 2 in o-ring, 1 in rubber washer, a large rubber washer and a small spring.
Put the spring on the nubbin in the bottom of hole on the top then put the the solid 1 in cylinder on top of spring. Glue the washer onto to the thing that has a hole going through it then glue it into the hole push it in far enough that the marble is touching the washer but not so far that it can't move. put the o-ring in the groove going around the main object. Glue the washer on to the bottom of the main object

author: Roborov

description.text:
Black Path is a 2-player board game that is played on a grid board invented in the 60s by Larry Black.

The Black Path Game is played on a board ruled into squares. Any square that is not empty is filled with one of the tiles, and there are two kinds of those.

Tiles are the three ways to join the sides of the square in pairs. The first two are the tiles of the Truchet tiling. One edge on the boundary of the board is designated to be the start of the path. The players alternate filling the square just after the end of the current path with one of the three configurations above, extending the path. The path may return to a previously filled square and follow the yet-unused segment on that square. The player who first causes the path to run back into the edge of the board loses the game.

-- Excerpt from
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Path_Game

To play,

Print as many of the two .stl as required.

the tiles are 4cm x 4cm x 2mm,
but you can scale it down 50% on every dimension for smaller prints

This is my 52 mm spool bearing made of washers. It works fine on a threaded rod. 
Set your parameters to change size and the amount of washers you want to use.
The photo shows a "SchweiÃŸdrahtspule" usually used for cut wire welding with the ID: DIN 8559, Typ RS 300/15 GZ

Set your own parameters in the wash2round_V2.scad-file and print your own bearing.
The "Springy" value should be set to 0.7 for a good elastic and stable bearing. Or you can print the wash2bush_V2_8mm.stl-file for a 52mm spool bearing mount.
You will need 10 M8 washers, 4 nuts and a M8 threaded rod. Update: My theory The threaded rods will get scratches over time. The bearing tends to follow the rotation on the threaded rod. But the movement up and down on the rod is blocked by washers and nuts. So the spinning on the rod might cause a rotation of the washers inside the bearing and the threaded rods get deeper scratches. Have fun with this composite thing! Because of the discovered weak spot shown in the picture, please prefer the build of version 4. Update: Version 4: (Pictures show version 2)
  • stronger build
  • washers are connected so the rod cannot get stuck

comments.text: Although very low cost, this seems like a high wear solution.  How does the threaded rod take the punishment?
comments.author: qharley

comments.text: I have seen some scretches on the washers till now. I think the threaded rod is harder than the washers.

title: Vive Tracker Vibration Mount - For Drones and Other High Frequency Oscillators

description.text:
Drone All Of The Things!

Want to mount an HTC Vive Tracker to a drone or other device which creates high frequency movement?

If you don't have vibration isolation your tracking accuracy will have a bad time (trust me, I tried).

This mount lets you access the Vive Tracker's pins, and uses standard anti-vibration rubber shock absorbing balls, which are commonly used when mounting cameras to drones.

It's remixed from Shiratch's excellent "Vive tracker pin connector convertible base"

What Else Do I Need?

  • 3 x Rubber shock absorbing balls, rated ~50g (I used these ones from Hobbyking)
  • 1/4" Hex-head bolt, around 1/4" long OR 1/4" Camera Mounting screw (Choose knob design based on screw option)

Optional

  • 3.96mm Right Angle Header Pins (like these ones), if you'd like to connect buttons or other electronic stuff. I used standard straight 0.1" headers, split them all apart, bent them with pliers and hot-glued them in place, because I am a terrible person.
  • Hookup wire, killer/silly ideas, disregard for the dangers of flying a drone inside, etc.

Attaching To Your Vibrating Object

I've included two base options: One which is just the right size to fit underneath a Vive Tracker, and a longer one which can more easily be taped/zip-tied to your drone/vehicle/thing of choice.

If you'd like to edit/remix this object yourself, I've made the design public on Tinkercad.

Video Time!

Here's a couple of videos of the mount in action:

https://vimeo.com/220018293

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a1Vv7i7rufo

title: FireMinions Wallock (the lockable wallet)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Note this is a work in progress. it is a conceptual model. I have ideas to make it slimmer and for the dials to be more accessible. I have not done any print tests yet as it still needs some support material.
I was looking up on these lockable hard cased wallets and thought it would be a good 3d print project instead of spending the money. I put plenty of thought into it and there are a few things I see I need to work on but as of this version I think it is now in a functional state. this version is 0.8. after I make a few tweaks I will call it 1.0.
Basically what I made a pocket sized cryptex in the shape of a wallet. most cryptex type containers are kind of limited for space and doesn't fit nicely in the pocket. this works much the same as a cryptex but shaped to fit in pocket or purse and offers more useable space inside the container. I made the hinge in a manner that resists being pried apart from the outside. once unlocked it can be taken apart. the number rings I used from the keychain cryptex. all other parts I made myself.

The file I submitted contains all parts and has not been optimized for 3d printing yet. some support will be needed to print out the case and the button latch parts. I will submit a version after I have added these to the model.

Note that this is a toy, prop, model. it does not have any mechanism to load, chamber or fire any kind of projectile the barrel is solid. I strongly suggest printing or painting the Muzzle brake or barrel in blaze orange to identify it as being a toy

This is a model of the M4 Carbine. I have tried to keep the level of realism and detail as high as possible while also making the model as 3D print friendly as possible.

A printer with a build volume of x250 Y210 z210 is capable of printing all the parts. the larger parts could be further cut up for printing on smaller printers if there is a demand I will do this.

The model is assembled with super glue and pins cut from 1.75mm filament (pins are probably enough to hold it together. some M4 Socket head screws are required and some assorted springs.

Many of the parts are spring loaded and function for added detail and realism.

I also plan to design and release many of the available accessories such as the M9 (bayonet), M203 (grenade launcher), suppressor, ACOG sights and more. however many of these real-life components are comparable eg. you could buy a cheap ACOG and it would be able to fit to the prop M4.

If you like this or any of my other designs and remixes think about tipping me a dollar $1 this will help keep me motivated and continue providing my work for free

Are you tired of fiddling with plugging in your USB cable? If you've mounted your electronics in the traditional location on a Prusa i3, chances are you have to navigate the bundle of extra wire behind your frame to do so. I know I've loathed that element of the single sheet design more than once.  
Never fear though, I've got a solution! Note: It's not a new idea as several variations exist for older Prusa and similar printers.  
Instead of contorting your hands or leaving your USB cable attached permanently, use my USB relocator!  
This thing uses a USB Female panel mount to Male cable to relocate the USB connector to the front of the printer. See photos.  
The cable I used: StarTech 1-Feet Panel Mount USB Cable B to B - F/M

1) Print object. I used 20% infill, 2 layers.
2) Attach panel mount to bracket.
3) Clip bracket to left side of Y-axis 10mm rod.
4) (optional) Use (2) 3mmx22mm bolts and (2) 3mm nuts to clamp to the Y-axis. Wasn't needed on my printer as it fits snug enough.
5) Route cable around the left side of the left Z-axis motor and plug the other end into your controller board. Note: you can use the .scad file to modify the opening or hole spacing as needed.

Hi!

This is a simple, clip on/slide on, filament guide that I made for my Anet A8. it'll fit on anything that is 8mm thick.

It clips/slides on the top part, right between the screen and the buttons.

What's different about this one is that it's in two parts (both parts are "joined" by the smallest possible bridge so you print both in one file then detach the side part)... The big part has a gap where you can slide in your filament (you have to take It off the printer to do that), and the small part fills that gap once you've put in your filament. I thought it'd look neater that way.

I printed at 60mm/s with 15% infill and it was fine, although printing at 30mm/s gave me a better finish..

sorry for the photo quality, taking good photos of black parts is really hard.

Oh! there are two separate STL files, one has a straight "middle", and the other one has a cross-shapped notch. I printed the straight one and it sits perfectly, but I thought having a notched one might be more secure. Print whatever you choose and comment about it.

*oh! the top is flat, so it prints perfectly upside down.... no need for supports or anything.

The torlo was born out of the idea of using a simple oscillating motor as a power source. The Voice coil of a scarp laptop HDD fit the bill nicely. The Voice coil with its powerful magnets has enough brunt to push a bunch of 3d printed gears .The basic idea of the torlo was adapted from the previous holo clock and taken further. The gears of the clock hang to one side and the rings to the other side of the frame. The voice coil is located in the center of the drive train and is driven by a attiny pulsing it every 2 seconds. The balance wheel when pulsed pushes a cam and a ratchet to turn the clock 2 seconds further. Rest of the clock is a simple drive train driving the minute and hour rings which display the time..

The clock is a slightly complex project because of the intricate printed parts needed. It is a little finicky to assemble and needs a lot of patience.
All the parts are printed with a 0.4mm nozzle at .2mm - .25mm layer height. The gears need to be a little loose so if the printer is not calibrated nicely they will freeze.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=urmw5Dx-LtU

https://www.tindie.com/products/ekaggrat/torlo/

title: Reach 3D large and small extruder gears

description.text:
These are some replacement gears for the Reach 3D printer. My extruder gears were loose and the set-screw wouldn't keep it in the right place. I designed this to eliminate the set-screw and smooth things out. It has worked really well and I never have to tighten it anymore. It takes a bit of a push to get the small gear pressed onto the stepper motor, but it holds really well once it's in place.

You'll have to lay them flat in your slicer before you convert them to gcode, I'm new at this still haven't figured out how to lay them down properly in the STL file. Let me know what you think :)

author: cwhicker

print_settings.Notes:: The bracket can be in PLA (though PETG probably better if your stepper gets hot), but the duct should be in PETG or ABS.

title: Titan Aero mount for Makerfarm Pegasus/i3v

description.text:
This is version two of my bracket/mount for a E3D Titan Aero on a Makerfarm Pegasus/i3v. I think it is basically finished and I'm happily using it on my printer. It includes an optional part fan and inductive autolevel probe. I'll probably tweak/improve the fan duct a little as time goes on and that small part can be printed separately.

The design files are on on onshape and you can edit them there (though please give credit if you use them).

If you decide to use the inductive probe, see various youtubes for instructions on how to attach it to your ramps board (carefully!). The marlin config file for my printer is here.

Update 6/19/2017: Better version of duct added
Update 6/21/2017: Even better version of duct (no whistle). Minor improvements to bracket.

Required parts:

  • Two 3mmx24 countersunk screws (for the fan)
  • Two 3mm locknuts (for the fan)
  • Two 4mmx16 bolts (for the carriage mount)
  • One 4mmx12 bolt (for the carriage mount)
  • A 50mm radial fan (optional), like this.
  • An inductive probe (optional), like this

Printer:

Pegasus 10"

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 (but I bet 0.32 would be fine)

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The bracket can be in PLA (though PETG probably better if your stepper gets hot), but the duct should be in PETG or ABS.

print_settings.Notes:: NOTE!!! I had to print with 0.2mm horizontal expansion in Cura in order for the scripture text to fully print (SketchUp didn't want to let me thicken the text in the CAD file). I'm also including a small section of the scripture reference for testing print settings to make sure the text prints properly.

description.text:
I love that I live in a nerdy town and go to a small church! My pastor found out that I got a 3D printer and commissioned a communion cup. This is what I came up with for my first ever self designed 3D print. I was originally trying to max out the build volume of my printer, so the model is quite large. I ended up printing it at 75% scale to be a more reasonable size.

I printed it in wood filament to make it a little more authentic, but anything would work. The tight resolution is due to the shallow angles and vertical curved surfaces. Anything larger would have shown significant stepping on the surface at the shallow angles.

NOTE!!! I had to print with 0.2mm horizontal expansion in Cura in order for the scripture text to fully print (SketchUp didn't want to let me thicken the text in the CAD file). I'm also including a small section of the scripture reference for testing print settings to make sure the text prints properly.

Printer:

I'm also including a small section of the scripture reference for testing print settings to make sure the text prints properly.

description.text:
I designed this to Calibrate any printer for stringing. The various distances and orientation will allow a quick way to test your printer for stringing so you can tune it out. I came up with it because I found that my printer when I got it not only had a bad stringing issue but it also had a directional stringing between close points. This will allow you to test all the way down to the 1mm distance.

Once you have figured out your retraction distance and speed these should just come out as solid rods with Zero stringing at all. Please share freely

title: 285753 Motor Coupling for Kenmore Direct Drive Top Load Washer

description.text:
The original design this is based on is for a smaller shaft than my Kenmore Model 110.92578410 has, though the rest of the dimensions are perfect. So I edited it in OpenSCAD for the 12.75mm diameter and 10.5mm notch shaft from my motor. The actual shaft size in the file is slightly larger to allow for some fiddle room in the print.

Fits my motor and got a broken washing machine working again. Thanks to OnShape for the original design.

This model has 100,000+ Mesh Faces, recommended to slow your printer speed to get the most detail out of it (perhaps 40mm-60mm/s for infills and perimeters)

Go high layer resolution on this one. 0.1mm Layer height will do the trick!

description.text:
I created this Strainer for draining the cover on my pool. I alway siphon off the top with scraps of hose and battle it getting constantly clog by debris or the by the cover getting sucked into the end and stopping the flow. After attaching this device to the hose I had no suction issues and got full flow the whole time even when immersed in leaves. It is a snug fit into the cut end of the hose and the whole device withstood the pressure of being pushed in.

I had no issues printing without supports I used a brim though I believe it should print fine without one.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dIbFnUiC0ss

title: yacs two arm largish coin spinner

description.text:
Yet another coin fidget spinner. This one is a somewhat larger two arm version.
The centre hole is for the standard 608 skate bearing, 22 mm × 7 mm.

There are a few ready-made STLs there, for coins i had lying around:

  • six 50 euro cent coins
  • eight UK 5p coins
  • eight 5 euro cent coins
  • eight 1 角人民币 (1 Jiao RMB) coins

(I did print all of these, but for the photo session could find only the one.)

This is slightly parametric. Whit a bit of work you can use your favourite coins, either local currencies, or parts of that little pile of foreign currency that travellers tend to collect. For that i have included the FreeCAD file. It includes a spreadsheet called “sizes”. To get a new spinner, do this:

  • Download FreeCAD and get it running
  • Load the yacs_2_arm.fcstd FreeCAD file
  • In the tree view, double click on “Sizes”. You should see the spreadsheet
  • Measure your coin or look up its size (Wikipedia, search engine, &c.)
  • Put in the diameter and thickness in B6 and B7. Make sure to keep the = and mm.
  • Check that you have enough coins. The spreadsheet shows the number needed. Typically 8, 6 for thicker coins like 10 euro cent and up.
  • Change other values in the “B” column, like the whole spinner’s size, to taste.
  • Go back to the yacs_2_arm view
  • Check that the shown shape looks OK. There are view controls at the top
  • Check that in the tree view there are no exclamation marks as warnings
  • If there are problems, it’s easiest to close without saving and to try again. Change fewer values, and only by small amounts.
  • If the spinner looks good, select the last item, “spinner”. It should turn green in the main view.
  • Look for the dropdown in the tool bar and select “Mesh Design”
  • You should now have a “Meshes” menu. Select “Create mesh from shape …”
  • I have to select the “Standard” radio button. “Mefisto” produces empty meshes.
  • Click OK
  • There should be a “spinner (Meshed)” item in the tree view. Select it.
  • Click on the “Export a mesh to file” icon, enter a file name, select the file type (STL or OBJ) and click “OK”,
  • Et voilà, you’re done. You have finished your first FreeCAD lesson and can now go ahead and slice and print your customized spinner.

There is also some design history available at my github repo.

All my “yacs” spinners are related and started out with the same bearing ring.

title: CUBETRIX diy corexy 3D PRINTER
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
3D Printing is an additive manufacturing process that creates a physical object from a digital design. There are different 3D printing technologies and materials you can print with, but all are based on the same principle: a digital model is turned into a solid three-dimensional physical object by adding material layer by layer.

Every 3D print starts as a digital 3D design file – like a blueprint – for a physical object. Trying to print without a design file is like trying to print a document on a sheet of paper without a text file.This design file is sliced into thin layers which is then sent to the 3D printer.  Chuck Hull invented the first 3D printing process called ‘stereolithography’ in 1983 and from this priciple, he built the foundation of what we now know today as additive manufacturing (AM) – or 3D printing.  In the same way ( almost ) I did it myself from a dream turned into design to create my own 3d printer with the name CUBETRIX.   

Thanks to open source we can program our printer to create almost any object.   As many of you have at home a prusa i3 clone with which I have spent more money than it should be spent: that if you have to modify the structure, that if you have to change the extruder and the list goes on and on and I decided to get down to work and create something much, much better at a price of a prusa clone.

CUBETRIX has 330x330x300 printing area, 32bits processor,32 steps per motor, 3.2 inches tft touchscreen, wlan and wifi conecion,10 times superior velocity compare to a i3 prusa clone,6 points autolevel ( depends of your config.) , very stable structure no more rare movements, leds on the extruder to better view of the prints, etc…….. But you can add any board/lcd you like: duet,ramps,etc… on this printer.  Without more ado I present my project:

With the files you will get the pdf on how to build/view the structure and the BOM (bill of materials )pdf file.

(Note: The mesurements are for 330x330x300 build volume If you intend to make a larger/smaller print area, then increase/decrese the length of the 20x20 extrusions and rods for each axis by the difference )

BILL OF MATERIALS here:https://www.dropbox.com/s/vcf8cn4iw92hkyd/CUBETRIX%20DYI%203D%20PRINTER%20BOM%20%28%20bill%20of%20materials%20%29.pdf?dl=0
Any components for 3d printers here: https://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-3D-Printer-and-Supplies-c-3533.html?p=T5241491383602017022

Everyone is going to say: Yes we have the files, but how are we going to build the printer, so comrades I have created videotutorials on how to build the CUBETRIX. Here there are:

author: MaxNoodle

description.text:
Bed leveling wedge

Ever wished you could just stick something between the nozzle and the bed to measure the distance? Now you can! :)

I've tried a lot of different manual and automatic bed leveling techniques and solutions over the past weeks and realized that each solution comes with it's own set of factors or in worst case calibration. Even after properly mounting and calibrating a z-probe I realized that having a physically level bed helps to avoid the need for any unnecessary software compensation.

So instead I chose a more simple approach to estimate the distance between the bed and the nozzle.

The wedge is a primitive mechanical ~4.5x magnifier that can be used to accurately measure any coordinate on your bed using a point of reference.

Materials needed

2x M2 20mm screws
2x M2 nuts
1x rubber band

Assembly instructions.

Assemble the wedge using two screws to resemble the forms on the image.
Thread the rubber band into the ridges around the body to act as a counter-weight.

Usage instruction

Raise the nozzle about 6-8 mm above the bed then choose a corner of your bed that will act as your point-of-reference.

Raise the dial-arm and wedge the device in under the nozzle and let go.
Make sure the nozzle is resting in the small groove on the wedge.

Once you have the wedge safely fixed under the nozzle , use the adjustment-screw on your corner to make the dial-arm on the wedge measure up to the long line on the middle of dial.

Repeat the procedure for the other corners until all readings line up to the same value as the first.

Celebrate and rejoice, your bed is level!

Update 8/10/2017
Added a combined printable version with R2 increased to 75mm for 6.2x magnification.
My description was off before, the regular 55mm version gives 4.5x magnification.

magnification
Update 27/08/2017
Removed obsolete files and cleaned up the description.

Update 07/08/2017
Modified the arm for easier reading.
I see that alot of people collected and downloaded this thing, please add a few photos/makes if you did one and liked it :)

Update 20/06/2017
Parametric V2 design added, source can be found here: https://github.com/telamon/bedwedge

title: Buell XB12R LED Headlight mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an adapter to mount the Highsider Satellite Headlights to the stock mount of the Buell XB Firebolt models.

The original ellipsoid headlights of the Buell Firebolt models have a low light output and tend to get even darker over time as the mirrors inside the lights turn dark grey.
Therefore a replacement was needed.
In the German XBORGFORUM there was a thread about LED Headlights used in a show bike built by Dirty Harry.
Those LED Headlights have about the right size to fit into the stock mask of the Buell Firebolt models. Additionally the lights have an European ECE-certification (high and low beam) so even by strict German law they are street legal.

(There is no integrated parking light. To make the whole bike street legal again you need to add a parking light with ECE-certification. See my pics or the XBORGFORUM for ideas)

By using the stock mount the beam adjuster can still be used.

I bought the lights at Louis in Germany but they are also available at other stores:
Louis Highsider Satellite low beam
Louis Highsider Satellite high beam

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Printed in PLA for testing.
Final version was printed in PETG and coated with some black color.

Introduction

You need to print two different mounts as the high and low beam lights don't have the same diameter.

PLA is brittle and doesn't like water and sun light too much. Therefore it would probably be better to print the thing in PETG/ABS or apply some coating to the PLA afterwards.

Mounting

Remove the mount delivered with the lights.
Use the screws to secure them into the printed mounts.
Screw the mounts onto your bike and attach the cables.

If you live in Europe and want it street legal: Don't forget the parking light!

title: Customisable Prusa i3 MK2 Rambo / Controller case - BASE

description.text:
You need firmware??

If you're building a MK2 clone with a RAMPS based board, you've got yourself a MK42, then you might want to run a port of the prusa firmware. See https://github.com/slippyr4/Prusa-Firmware

What is this?

This is a customisable, parameterised rework of the Original Prusa i3 MK2 case. Find the original in Prusa's github repository at https://github.com/prusa3d/Original-Prusa-i3/tree/MK2

The original SCAD is designed around the Rambo Mini 1.3 board and I wanted to use a different board. So i've reworked the SCAD file to make the board dimensions into parameters so it can work with a lot of different controller boards.

You need to enter the length and width of the PCB of your controller board, and the offset from the board edge to the mounting holes. There are two more parameters which are optional - top gap - which adds extra spacing between the PCB and the top of the case. That's not needed on the RAMBO mini, but a value of 6 works well for MKS boards. There's also an HBP offset parameter which optionally moves the HBP cable entry assembly up or down. This was needed for the MKS base because the original location of the HBP cable entry fouled the USB socket.

The RAMBO mini has the USB cutout on the top edge, that's deleted from this design. I've not added the facility to put a new cutout for your board in this customiser. You could download the SCAD and do it yourself, or just get handy with a scalpel when you've printed it.

I recommend you print in PETG if you can, but any plastic would do.

If you print this you will also need to print the DOOR (see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2370625) and also the hinges (which are unchanged from the prusa original). When customising the DOOR part, use the exact same values for the parameters as here, or it won't line up and fit.

To help you out:-

MKS SBASE

Board Length 146.5
Hole Offset 4
Board Width 95
Top Gap 6
HBP Offset 0

MKS Base

Board Length 110
Hole Offset 5
Board Width 90
Top Gap 0
HBP Offset -6

RAMBO mini

Board Length 103
Hole Offset 4
Board Width 69
Top Gap 0
HBP Offset 0

comments.text:

author: OgoSport

title: Customisable Prusa i3 MK2 Rambo / Controller case - DOOR

description.text:
You need firmware??

If you're building a MK2 clone with a RAMPS based board, you've got yourself a MK42, then you might want to run a port of the prusa firmware. See https://github.com/slippyr4/Prusa-Firmware

What is this?

This is a customisable, parameterised rework of the Original Prusa i3 MK2 case. Find the original in Prusa's github repository at https://github.com/prusa3d/Original-Prusa-i3/tree/MK2

The original SCAD is designed around the Rambo Mini 1.3 board and I wanted to use a different board. So i've reworked the SCAD file to make the board dimensions into parameters so it can work with a lot of different controller boards.

You need to enter the length and width of the PCB of your controller board, and the offset from the board edge to the mounting holes. There are two more parameters which are optional - top gap - which adds extra spacing between the PCB and the top of the case. That's not needed on the RAMBO mini, but a value of 6 works well for MKS boards. There's also an HBP offset parameter which optionally moves the HBP cable entry assembly up or down. This was needed for the MKS base because the original location of the HBP cable entry fouled the USB socket.

The RAMBO mini has the USB cutout on the top edge, that's deleted from this design. I've not added the facility to put a new cutout for your board in this customiser. You could download the SCAD and do it yourself, or just get handy with a scalpel when you've printed it.

I recommend you print in PETG if you can, but any plastic would do.

If you print this you will also need to print the BASE (see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2370602) and also the hinges (which are unchanged from the prusa original). When customising the BASE part, use the exact same values for the parameters as here, or it won't line up and fit.

To help you out:-

MKS SBASE

Board Length 146.5
Hole Offset 4
Board Width 95
Top Gap 6
HBP Offset 0

MKS Base

Board Length 110
Hole Offset 5
Board Width 90
Top Gap 0
HBP Offset -6

RAMBO mini

Board Length 103
Hole Offset 4
Board Width 69
Top Gap 0
HBP Offset 0

author: 3Dpassion

description.text:
A snap on mount for IKEA LEDBERG led strip.

I printed it standing on the side for better strength, without supports, this works but it will not look perfect (the overhang will not be horizontal).

It's also possible to slice laying flat on the mounting plate. This will give better appearance but slightly more fragile.

This is a water drop hitting the ground frozen in time.  
It was modeled using Blender's fluids engine.  Blender was built for movies and video games and it rocks for that.  But its fluids modeler is pretty primitive.  It tends to impose a subtle square geometry on everything.  But it is still a spectacular print.  
I would love to see what a real CFD modeler could produce.  
I'll post a tutorial if anyone is interested.

comments.text: I'm looking into making an sculpture with dripping water- but I don't know the first thing about Blender. A tutorial would be lovely! It looks so good.

title: Filament holder assembly for the IKEA LACK STUVA enclosure

description.text:
This is a curtain rod holder and filament roll holders that shall hang on the curtain rod.

The filament holders shall be printed in pairs with one mirrored. Then use electric tube with 16mm diameter as an axis to keep them parallell.

The curtain rod holders shall also be printed in pairs, with one of them mirrored. I printed them without supports and ppeled away some of the filament that was hanging. Use support if you prefer.

The idea came from the guide at https://github.com/PrusaMK2Users/MK2_Tips_and_Tricks/wiki/IKEA-LACK-STUVA-enclosure but the liks were broken to some of the printable parts so I made some new ones.

The Lords of the Beyond after being banished left behind a large strip of devastated land, with ghost towns, buildings, temples and a whole range of localities. Rumors that in these places existed treasures, weapons and a whole range of fantastic things, began to arrive in the ears of the people of our world.

Individuals in search of fame and fortune have decided to enter these cursed lands in search of these prizes. Organized in small groups, they enter these lands and there they face dangers. This is the premise of Scavengers, a skirmish game in the devastated lands, where you lead a group of adventurers in search of fame and fortune.

Extracted from Alabar Chronicle´s, a Scavenger Guide to Our World"

Introduction

Scavengers is a table top miniature war game for fighting skirmishes with fantasy/steampunk figures. Two players fight a small scale combat with five to ten miniatures on each side (a hero and your henchmen). The game is easy to learn and play, though there is enough depth that it will take time and experience to master.

The game was designed around three core premises.

a) You can download our 3D models or use any miniatures in their collection. Thus, the game is not specifically designed to any particular manufacturer or company. But if you like to help the game dev, please download our models! (They are free and paid...)

b) It is important that the miniatures on the table be the focus of the game. In the end, miniature gaming should be about miniatures (and fun!)

c) A large background - We´ll develop new units, histories and game scenarios. But we need your help, sending suggestions to improve the game!

I hope you like our game and have fun! Ahh, an important thing: this is the basic core rules, our idea is releasing other books to improve the game!

This is a human airship and you need to print 1 for a stand. Our gaming site is coming with our core book, game lore and a lot of new things!

author: bluesmurf345

description.text:
Some day I was stucked thinking about some new design flaws, vaping a little and making some O-rings and tricks waiting for the inspiration to come. Suddenly I noticed that would be cool doing more than vapor O-Rings and wondered if I could make X-Rings, then this design came to my mind. Just put the main tube in your mouth and make little puffs usual, it will emit vapor X's. Cool like magic. To remove or change the cap simply press it out with a pencil or something alike. Also after playing with this and make some XRings I found the solution to the design flaw I was thinking about initially.

Two part print. The main tube that can be used alone to make perfect giant O-Rings, or press fitting the X-Cap to make vapor X-Rings. Easy print, no support required.

Other thoughts:
I am wondering if it could be done some design to make vapor ships like Gandalf does... Maybe I add some other cap variants in the future hehe...

UPDATE 08-JUN-2017: V2. Enhanced design to cilyndric fit. I don't know why I did it conical!! DOH! XRing redesigned air flux (V1 didn't work at all, maybe this is not possible at this size), increased diameter for the 5-O-Ring for the same reason.
